snippet: A torn A.C.L., like that sustained by Mariano Rivera, is a relatively rare injury in baseball. But there appears to be little that would prevent him from pitching again.
abstract: Torn ACL like that sustained by New York Yankees closer Mariano Rivera is a relatively rare injury in baseball; experts say there is little reason that the injury would prevent him from pitching again. Photo (M)

byline.original: By ANDREW KEH; Tyler Kepner contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: Yankees closer Mariano Rivera declared Friday that his career was not over, and according to medical experts and peers who have come back from a similar knee injury, there is no reason to believe he will not be able to return. Rivera, who tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee Thursday night, faces a recovery process that could last up to eight months. It is a relatively rare injury among baseball players, much less pitchers. Nevertheless, there does not appear to be much, including his age, that would prevent the 42-year-old Rivera from pitching again.

headline.main: Uncommon Injury for Pitchers; Positive Signs for Rivera
